children.subject: Nah, but really, if you look at the pinned post by Professor Abbeel regarding CS 287, his requirements for undergraduates wanting to take the class is basically A+es in certain classes, so I guess A+es could help with that kind of thing where the professor really wants to select a handful of students for something.
Yep! This is especially true in cases where 40% of the class get straight As.

^ What specific classes/professors/offerings are you referring to when you talk about "cases where 40% of the class get straight As"? I've never even seen a CS class grade distribution with 40% A grades on Berkeleytime.
61B with Hilfinger, 189 with Sahai, CS 186 with Hellerstein last couple semesters, the last iteration of CS 169 available on BerkeleyTime, to name a few.

Even if that is the case, the preponderance of classes in EECS (especially those that require more mathematical maturity) don't have that sort of grade distribution, given departmental guidelines and empirical data from across classes. I am firmly in the position an A+ grade is a terrible indicator of additional academic achievement over an A grade, especially since there is no GPA difference between an A and an A+.

In fact, some professors in the Math department use the level of personal rapport and familiarity with students to determine the boundary between A and A+ grades.

both 126 and 127 have about 40% getting As and above (34%), which are the go-to examples of classes with mathematical maturity. in this case, getting an A+ is purely determined by the score you get in comparison to those of your classmates.
To the answers above, According to Berkeley time, eecs127 gets less than 20% A and A+ fall 18 and cs189 only gives 4 A+(not 4%) in fall 18, so it's high variation among semesters
Just want to add some other curves, Prof Dan Garcia gave out around 20% A and in addition 20% A+ in 61c
Bragging rights. Everyone loves a flex

history.content: Some professors might require it for grad coursework and research (although this is very rare as A’s suffice). Other than that, simply bragging rights.

children.subject: A lot of researches explicitly asks you to have certain numbers of A+ on average per semester
hahah u right

+1 If someone thinks a metric as flawed and indicative of really nothing else but an unnecessary amount of time spent on coursework (for most people) is useful in determining whether you are qualified to learn something new or work on some challenging problems, I would seriously question whether you want to be surrounded by what this structure incentivizes or if you can gain equivalent knowledge/work experience in an environment that values other aspects of people's lives more.
+1000 anyone who thinks like that isn’t worth working with

The metric is indicative of more than just unnecessary amount of time. It indicates your level of knowledge in the course is in the top echelon, which is exactly what research labs want out of undergrads.
Hmmm I was able to get into a couple research labs that friends with A+s and better grades weren’t so I wouldn’t say that’s true.

You can always finesse positions that you are not necessarily the most qualified for, of course. It happens all the time with college decisions where more deserving candidates get screwed over in favor of weaker candidates because of a variety of reasons, reasons that are not necessarily the same as those in this context. But an A+ definitely is indicative of being more qualified in the subject matter than an A in my opinion, simply because of their rarity for most given technical classes. Saying all of this as a neutral party that doesn't care much about grades, and has had but 1 A+ and very few As in my time here, and has never put in the kind of sustained effort that the regular A/A+ kids do.

I think you're bs-ing people here. First of all, the A/A+ differential only exists for technical majors; its almost laughable how easy it is to get an A+ for some of the breadth courses. Secondly, an A+ just means you're a great test-taker (for most courses where tests make up most of your grade) and not necessarily that you understand the material better than other people in the class, which I agree is correlated but it cannot be definitively ascertained as an indicator of understanding material or success in research. And as with every success, there is a good degree of luck involved in getting that A+ (professors, test grading, etc.). Therefore, getting an A+ doesn't make you "deserve" any of the positions significantly more than your peers, although I understand that it does make it easier to catch the attention of research labs and for them to "trust" you when you demonstrate interest.

I did mention the context as belonging to "technical classes" ("But an A+ definitely is indicative of being more qualified in the subject matter than an A in my opinion, simply because of their rarity for most given technical classes"); nowhere did I mention anything about breadths lol. And like you said, there is a decently strong correlation between getting an A+ vs. an A and having a stronger understanding, but that's really the only point of difference being discussed here between two candidates. Sure, you can also vet candidates with relevant technical interviews to see if the A+ kid is actually legitimately better than the A kid, but everything else equal, you would choose the A+ kid as opposed to the A kid. It's not necessarily significant (i.e. the A wouldn't break your chances in nearly any case, since you can always try to out-finesse the field), but it is a difference to be considered for the really selective positions. I feel like we are arguing the same point, but with slightly different levels of emphasis on the relative importance of various factors. I also think my college analogy wasn't the best to use in hindsight, but it's similar in that merely the highest scores don't always get you the position you want.

I just don't agree that if you don't get an A+, you'll have to "finesse" positions lol. I think I brought it out pretty clearly that getting an A+ doesn't make you "deserve" the position more nor makes you more "qualified" simply because of the external factors involved. Moreover, like you yourself mentioned, you don't seem to have enough A+s or experience with research labs to effectively gauge the difference it makes, so I think its better if you admit that rather than spewing your own opinion all over here.

I still maintain that there is still no incentive at all for professors to give out A+ grades according to any basis of superior performance on coursework. Hell, what's to stop a professor from simply giving all students in the top grade bracket A+s, and simply not give any student an A?

Empirically, CS professors do give A+ grades purely based on your objective standing in the course, and that the number of A+s handed out is far fewer than the number of As. 

On why professors migh choose A+s as a metric for selecting undergrad researchers: you have 50 undergrads applying to 3 positions, and your time is worth over $250/hour. You don't care about false negatives so much as avoiding false positives (students who look strong but aren't), so the optimal strategy is to take the top 5 based on resume/transcript, and then filter that down to 3.

Choosing students based on grades is much more susceptible to false positives, especially if you're using A+s as a metric where the difference between an A and an A+ is often based on luck or spending an unreasonable amount of time on a class (rather than some sort of extracurricular activity) not to mention the fact that an A+ offers no gains to the students in terms of GPA...
I'm not saying to not take grades into account at all, in fact its very clear that someone with a 2.0 GPA should definitely focus on classes rather than research. But the empirical skill or talent or whatever you want to call it of a student with a high GPA with no A+s vs a student with the same GPA and many A+s is indistinguishable at best and in favor of the student with no A+s at worst (because that student likely had much more time to develop skills outside of test-taking). 
I think its very obvious that grades are correlated with likelihood of success, that is obvious. I also think its very clear that this correlation breaks down quite a lot when you consider a pool of students with only high GPAs, there's a huge diminishing of returns with grades especially when its between an A and an A+ which again is literally the same grade at this school in terms of GPA.

I think the better question is why you would even want to work for someone/participate is something that requires a certain number of A+s at a school where getting an A+ doesn't even give you an advantage in GPA over an A...

If you are aiming for some particular program for graduate school, say NLP, mentioning A+ grade for classes like 182 or 189 would certainly put you on the edge. But I guess if you are getting A+ in those competitive courses, your other curriculum would probably sufficient enough for demonstrating your skill....
Apart from admission to labs and certain classes as an undergrad, can anyone give some insight about how A vs. A+ grades are regarded during graduate admissions?

history.subject: What is the advantage of an A+ in a class?
